conclusion: Two sliders A and B with mass m are connected by a rope on an inclined plane with angle 37 degrees. Force F is applied to B, and both are on the verge of not sliding upwards. Coefficient of friction is 0.5, and sin 37° = 0.6.
Both sliders are connected by a rope, so they'll move together if they do move. The net force acting on them is zero because they're about to move but haven't started yet.
Static friction force is acting downwards along the incline at its maximum value, equal to kinetic friction force. Friction force formula is f = μN.
Normal force N is perpendicular to the inclined plane, calculated as mg cosθ.
Given both sliders are identical and connected by a rope, their accelerations would be the same if they were to move. Since they're on the verge of moving, their accelerations are zero.
Drawing a free-body diagram for each slider helps understand the forces acting on them.

Slider A has weight mg acting downwards vertically, normal force Na perpendicular to the incline upwards, friction force fa acting downwards along the incline, and tension T in the rope pulling upwards along the incline.

Slider B has weight mg acting downwards vertically, normal force Nb perpendicular to the incline upwards, friction force fb acting downwards along the incline, tension T' in the rope pulling downwards along the incline, and applied horizontal force F acting to the right.
Tension in the rope should be the same for both sliders, meaning T = T'.
The rope is light, so it doesn't add any mass or weight.
Resolve forces for slider A along the incline: component of weight is mg sinθ, friction force fa is μNa acting downwards, tension T acts upwards.
Net force along the incline for slider A is ΣFa = -mg sinθ + μNa + T = 0, since acceleration is zero.
Resolve forces for slider B along the incline: component of weight is mg sinθ, friction force fb acts upwards, tension T' acts downwards, horizontal force F has a component along the incline.
Horizontal force F applied to slider B needs to be resolved into components parallel and perpendicular to the incline.
Component of F along the incline is F cosθ, and component perpendicular to the incline is F sinθ.
Incline is at 37 degrees above the horizontal, angle between horizontal force F and incline is 90° - θ = 53 degrees.
